title.rendered: New Logo and Packaging for Itaipava by Futurebrand

content.rendered:
First brewed in 1994, Itaipava is a line of beers available in Brazil produced by Grupo Petrópolis. Its signature beer, a pilsner (or pislen in Portuguese), is the fourth most popular beer behind powerhouse brands from AmBev (Skol, Brahma, Antarctica). Itaipava will begin rolling out new packaging for its pilsner, designed by the São Paulo office of Futurebrand.

All product photography by Pict Estúdio.

Itaipava’s new identity puts the brand ahead of the old visual standards in its category and generates a lot of impact and interest on all touch points.

To crown these changes, a new brand icon has been born: a visual symbol that synthetizes all features and works as an Itaipava signature, setting a milestone for one of the most beloved brands in Brazil.

Futurebrand project page

In general, the old look — from logo to packaging — was surprisingly good for a mainstream beer. The logo with the flared serifs was a decent piece of lettering but suffered from poor stroking and I wouldn’t be doing my job if I didn’t point out the Amazon River-wide kerning gap between the “AV” pair. The new logo maintains the flared serif approach but goes with a more condensed structure and tilts the typography upwards, giving it a quick burst of energy. Given how difficult these set of letters are to kern, at an angle no less — you try it hotshot — this is very well resolved and a very convincing wordmark with great rhythm. The new logo implements a slightly oversized crown drawing that becomes a key device throughout the packaging. It’s a nice, simple depiction of a crown and I like how the thick line interacts with the thin line by interlocking and generating two sharp shadows (that look best on dark backgrounds).

The old cans and bottles weren’t terrible in their overall impression but once you got into the details it didn’t quite hold up. Every illustration element — hops, crown, mountains, other crown — was in a different style and the only thing holding them together was, literally, a holding shape that, itself, had a different style. Yet somehow, as a whole (and when seen from afar or as a small JPG), it worked. The new packaging does a fresh restart instead of trying to maintain shelf consistency and is all the better for it.

The angle of the logo drives the layout of the packaging with a strong diagonal giving the cans and bottle labels a bold, gold top; a large logo, and then plenty of luxurious white space. On the cans and labels, the combination of the crown, the diagonal, and the fully white space where there is no line pattern it looks like an implied sword (or a Latin cross) both of which are not bad subconscious images to see in a beer. Maybe it’s the very effective product shots but I really like the overall vibe of the new look.

The renders of additional products and accompanying objects are entertaining — that fridge! with the angled ventilation at the bottom! — but start to feel a little repetitive, which is not a terrible thing as it’s all about consistency but it’s almost like Russian nesting dolls with the same thing inside the same thing. Overall, a major improvement that brings both energy and finesse to the packaging and the larger presence of the brand.
